body_text.text: "influenza". Type 4 has been found in infants with acute respiratory disease but its role is not fully understood.

In 1956 Morris and others recovered a virus from a chimpanzee with a cold, which they aptly named chimpanzee coryza agent (CCA). The following year Chanock and his co-workers isolated the same agent from children with pneumonia and renamed it respiratory syncytial (RS) virus from its ability to provoke large syncytia in tissue cultures. Gradually evidence has accumulated that RS virus is an important cause of acute respiratory disease in young children. Although respiratory syncytial virus has been provisionally classified with the myxoviruses, it does not grow in chick embryo and does not show haemagglutination or haemadsorption. Since the virus is very sensitive to freezing and does not survive long at room temperature cultures must be inoculated by the bedside. RS virus grows well on Hela or HEp II cell lines but less well on monkey-kidney. Three serotypes have been identified. FIG. 57 . Hela cell culture, three days after inoculation with respiratory syncytial virus, showing one large syncytium full of cell nuclei.

In infants RS virus is the main cause of bronchiolitis but it has also been recovered from young children with pneumonia, coryza and mild "influenza". In adults RS virus is responsible for a small proportion of colds. There is serological evidence that it may initiate acute exacerba tions in patients with chronic bronchitis. RS antibodies are found in 60-80 per cent, of older children and adults.

Measles Virus. Measles virus has been discussed in Chapter 8 but is included because it is a common cause of respiratory disease. In classical measles changes may be found throughout the respiratory tract but giant cell pneumonia is known to occur in children with no history of a rash.
(2) Adenoviruses

Since 1953, when adenoviruses were first recovered from adenoids removed at operation, over 30 serotypes have been discovered in man and many others in animals, including primates, dogs, mice, cattle and birds. Adenoviruses appear to be a common cause of respiratory disease in young children and military recruits but are not of major importance in the general population.

Adenoviruses have an icosahedral structure, 70-90 nm in diameter, with an internal core of deoxyribonucleic acid. They grow readily on tissue culture of Hela cells, producing degeneration and causing the cells to fall off the glass in rounded clumps. Adenoviruses possess a common complement-fixing antigen but may be typed by a specific antigen, demonstrated by neutralisation tests in tissue cultures. Serotypes may be identified by their ability to agglutinate rat and rhesus erythrocytes. In contrast to influenza, adenoviruses of many different serotypes may be present simultaneously in a community. FIG. 58 . Electron micrograph of adenovirus (x 300,000) showing hexagonal profile and beaded surface. The virus particle is composed of 252 hollow polygonal subunits.

The pattern of infection varies with different serotypes. Some, such as types 3, 4 and 7, cause outbreaks of pharyngitis or of bronchitis and viral pneumonia. Others, types 1, 2 and 5, appear to be endemic in healthy infants and children. Latent viruses have been detected in 50-90 per cent, of adenoids and tonsils removed at operation. Pharyngo-conjunctival fever, a combination of pharyngitis with conjunctivitis following swimming, has been associated with types 3 and 7. Kerato-conjunctivitis without pharyngitis, found particularly in shipyard workers, is related to type 8 virus. Types 14 and 21 have been found in outbreaks of acute respiratory disease in military recruits. Adenoviruses multiply in the bowel and may be excreted for long periods. They have been associated with gastro-intestinal symptoms of diarrhoea, abdominal pain and vomiting. Controlled trials have suggested that they may precipitate intussusception in young children. Type 12 has been recovered from children with a spasmodic cough resembling whooping cough. Three serotypes (7, 12 and 18) produce tumours in suckling hamsters but have not been shown to cause tumours in man.

Picornaviruses are small (pico) viruses containing ribonucleic acid (RNA). They measure 15-30 nm and are resistant to ether. The group is very large and includes the enteroviruses and the rhinoviruses.

Enteroviruses. Since the properties of the enteroviruses have been described in Chapter 18 only a brief account is necessary of their role in acute respiratory disease. All three subgroups, the polioviruses, the Coxsackie and ECHO viruses multiply in the pharynx as well as the intestinal tract of man.
Polioviruses. Mild poliomyelitis may simulate an upper respiratory infection with fever and sore throat. Coryza is not a feature.

Coxsackie Viruses. Coxsackie A viruses 1-10 may produce herpangina with a vesicular enanthem on the soft palate. Coxsackie virus AIO has been isolated from patients with a nodular eruption on the soft palate, uvula and anterior pillars-lymphonodular pharyngitis. Coxsackie virus A21 (Coe virus) has been responsible for large outbreaks of colds or influenza-like disease in service men but rarely affects civilians. Viruses of the B group may be associated with mild upper respiratory disease.

ECHO Viruses. Several ECHO viruses have been found in children with respiratory infections. Type 11 has been isolated from children with croup and type 20 from children with fever, coryza, pharyngitis and abnormal stools. Types 13 and 25 have been recovered from sporadic cases of respiratory disease. ECHO type 10 virus has now been reclassified in a separate group, Reoviruses, and type 28 with the rhinovirus group.

Rhinoviruses. These are fastidious in their requirements and grow best on human embryo kidney cells or human diploid fibroblasts at a slightly lower temperature (33°C) and pH than enteroviruses. They also differ from enteroviruses in their sensitivity to weak acid. There are two strains, H and M, and over 100 serotypes. The M strain is less common and differs from the H strain by its ability to grow on monkey-kidney cells. Rhinoviruses have been recovered from the nose and throat but not from the bowel. They may be found in apparently healthy individuals but are usually isolated from children and adults with colds and can sometimes cause lower respiratory tract disease. The M group may be associated with influenza-like illness. The duration of immunity to rhinovirus infection is not known but is limited to the homologous serotype. Antibodies develop in approximately half the patients infected with H strains and in most patients infected with M strains. The high frequency of rhinovirus infections is due to the large numbers of serotypes and the short dominance of any one serotype in the community.

Reoviruses were formerly known as ECHO virus type 10 but were reclassified because they are larger than the enteroviruses, 75 nm and are stable at 50°C. There are three distinct serotypes with a wide range of hosts including man and many mammals. Although they have been recovered from throat or rectal swabs taken from children with mild upper respiratory symptoms or diarrhoea their significance in human disease is not fully understood. Antibodies to reoviruses types 1 and 3 appear in children about the end of the second year of life and reach a peak by the tenth year. Sixty per cent, of older children and adults possess antibodies to types 1 and 3 but few adults over 20 years have antibodies to type 2.

Herpes simplex virus, varicella-zoster virus and cytomegalovirus have a similar structure with a core of deoxyribonucleic acid. They form eosinophilic type A intranuclear inclusion bodies, are sensitive to ether and acid.

Herpes simplex virus is a common cause of gingivostomatitis in children and may cause pneumonia-see Chapter 3. (Herpesvirus varicellae) . Varicella-zoster virus may cause a viral type of pneumonia in adults (Chapter 4).

Pneumonia is a feature of generalised cytomegalic inclusion disease which may occur in new-born infants, many of whom are premature and in adults with deficiencies of immunity. Typical inclusion bodies may be detected in exfoliated cells present in urine or gastric contents and found in the liver at biopsy. Cytomegalovirus may be grown from urine or liver in human fibroblastic tissue cultures. Neutralising and complement-fixing antibodies are found in infected infants and their mothers. Asymptomatic infection is common in older children.
(6) Chlamydia (Psittacosis-ornithosis agent).

The chlamydia occupy a position between the viruses and rickettsiae. They differ from viruses by their large size, by a complex cycle involving multiplication by binary fission within cells and by their susceptibility to a number of antibiotics including tetracycline and penicillin. They may be propagated in mice, chick embryo and cultures of Hela cells or monkey-kidney cells. Chlamydia psittaci, the agent causing psittacosis, is widely distributed amongst birds and has already been demonstrated in nearly 100 species. In birds the infection is usually symptomless but may cause disease when conditions are unhygienic. The illness is very variable, taking the form of a gastro intestinal disturbance in adult birds but may present as a respiratory illness in young birds. Healthy birds may excrete chlamydiae for long periods. Man is occasionally infected by inhaling dust from dried excreta or feathers or by handling carcasses of infected birds. Chlamydia vary greatly in virulence for man and animals, those derived from parakeets and turkeys being more dangerous than those from pigeons and ducks. Budgerigars, dying from natural causes, do not appear to be an important source of psittacosis in Britain. Transmission from man to man is rare but well authenticated among hospital staff caring for patients with psittacosis. Chlamydiae are notoriously dangerous to handle in the laboratory and the greatest care must be taken with infected tissues. Infection in man may be subclinical or may produce a mild feverish illness resembling influenza or present as atypical pneumonia but fortunately the classical attack with fulminating pneumonia is rare. Before restrictions on the importation of parrots into the United Kingdom were removed in 1966 about 40 cases of psittacosis were reported each year; in 1972 the number had arisen to 156. In England about 1 per cent, of the general population possess antibody to Chlamydia psittaci; among people dealing with birds the incidence is 5 per cent.

In 1944 Eaton and others, investigating patients with primary atypical pneumonia, isolated an agent in chick-embryo culture which could be transmitted to cotton rats and hamsters. The resulting pneumonia could be prevented by serum from convalescent patients. Eaton agent was later propagated in monkey-kidney cell culture. In 1962 a relationship between Eaton agent and pleuropneumonia-like organisms (PPLO) was confirmed by Chanock and his co-workers who succeeded in growing it on PPLO agar medium supplemented by horse serum and yeast extract. The organism was identified as a mycoplasma and is now known as Mycoplasma pneumoniae which differs antigenically from other species of the PPLO group found in the respiratory and genital tracts of man.

Infection with mycoplasma may be silent or give rise to respiratory syndromes ranging in severity from mild respiratory disease to primary atypical pneumonia. It infects all ages but pneumonia is most common in school-age children and young adults. The organism may be isolated from the pharynx many weeks after the onset of illness even if appropriate antibiotics have been given. More rarely Mycoplasma pneumoniae is responsible for otitis media and bullous myringitis in which haemorrhagic bullae are found on the ear drum. It is also associated with a variety of non-respiratory conditions including encephalitis, polyneuritis, pericarditis and polyarthritis resembling rheumatic fever. Mycoplasma infection may precipitate auto-immune disorders such as haemolytic anaemia with high titres of cold-agglutinins, Stevens-Johnson syndrome and less severe forms of erythema multiforme.

Two main epidemiological patterns are discernible. In closed communities Mycoplasma pneumoniae may be responsible for large epidemics of pneumonia whereas in the general com munity it occurs throughout the year though often prominent in the late summer and autumn when other respiratory infections are seldom encountered. Probably as a result of the long incuba tion period and the prolonged carrier state infection tends to spread in leisurely fashion through family groups. About 20 per cent, of the young adult population in the London area possess complement-fixing antibody and patients with chronic bronchitis have been shown to have twice the amount of antibody found in control groups of a similar age.

In 1937 Derrick described an unusual (Query) fever among abbatoir workers in Australia. The causative organism was first identified as a rickettsia but was later classified separately as Coxiella burneti. It is a pleomorphic organism containing both DNA and RNA. Although morphologically indistinguishable from rickettsiae it differs in a number of important qualities. It is very resistant to drying and is sensitive to the antibiotic thiomycetin. It seldom causes rashes in man and does not stimulate the production of antibodies against the Proteus X strains as do the rickettsiae. During the Mediterranean campaign of 1944-45 this rickettsia-like organism was incriminated as the cause of atypical pneumonia occurring among soldiers in Italy and the Balkans. Subsequently localised outbreaks of Q fever have been identified in many parts of the world and infection has been found to be widespread in cattle, sheep, goats and other animals. In these farm animals infection is subclinical but large numbers of coxiellae are discharged in urine, faeces and milk and from the genital tract at parturition, resulting in heavy contamination of the environment. Infection usually spreads by inhalation of infected dust but may be acquired by drinking infected milk and in some parts of the world, notably Australia, may be transmitted from animal to animal by ticks. Coxiella burneti is a dangerous organism to culture and infection spreads readily in laboratories. Direct spread from man to man has been observed but is rare.

In Britain Q fever is a rural rather than an urban disease and is derived mainly from sheep or cattle. There is a seasonal variation among shepherds at lambing times; among herdsmen the incidence does not vary throughout the year. Antibodies have been detected in 20 per cent, of veterinarians, 29 per cent, of abattoir workers, 13 per cent, of farmers and only 1-9 per cent, of town dwellers.

Seasonal Incidence and Distribution. Although respiratory infections may occur at any time of year the incidence waxes and wanes with the seasons. In autumn the return of children to school is followed by a sharp rise in respiratory disease. Further peaks occur in November and December with acute illness in patients suffering from chronic bronchitis. A lull at Christmas is followed by a further rise in January, then a wave of colds and lower respiratory disease in March and April. The factors determining these seasonal fluctuations are little understood but there is correlation with low soil temperature and dry air in heated dwellings. Respiratory infections associated with enteroviruses occur during the summer whereas outbreaks due to respiratory syncytial virus are found in the winter. Rhinoviruses, parainfluenza viruses and reoviruses may be found throughout the year. Respiratory viruses have a world distribution and are as prevalent in the tropics as the temperate zones. They may even be found in remote oceanic islands though there is a tendency for rhinoviruses to disappear in such closed communities. Respiratory disease is particularly common in nurseries, schools, camps for military recruits and in families with a young child of school age.

Age Incidence. The incidence and pattern of respiratory infection is greatly influenced by age. The very young quickly lose their maternal antibodies and are immersed unprotected in a sea of respiratory viruses. Children under three years are particularly vulnerable and children of all ages have twice as much respiratory disease as adults. In the young, respiratory syncytial virus is an important cause of lower respiratory disease but immunity forms rapidly and 60 per cent. of older children possess antibodies. Parainfluenza infection is primarily a disease of children between the ages of six months and four years, in whom it commonly causes croup, but occasion ally it may spread to adults producing mild upper respiratory symptoms. Antibodies to adenoviruses, types 1, 2 and 5, are formed early in life but antibodies to types 3, 4 and 7 appear later. Outbreaks of adenovirus infection in adults may occur in military camps but are rarely found in civilian life. Coxsackie A21 (Coe) virus produces respiratory disease in military recruits. Although mycoplasma infection occurs mainly in the second and third decades this agent may be responsible for 10 per cent, of serious respiratory infection in children. Rhinoviruses cause colds in all age groups.

Adenovirus infections producing conjunctivitis have been associated with swimming baths and shipyards. Q fever has been found in meat packers, dairy farmers and others coming in contact with cattle and sheep. Milk may be contaminated and infection has spread from contaminated straw. Ornithosis follows exposure to infected birds, the most dangerous being parrots, parakeets and turkeys. Women are most susceptible to respiratory infections at the beginning and end of the menstrual cycle presumably from variations in the nasal mucosa resulting from the action of hormones.

It is generally believed that respiratory viruses are spread through the air by droplets expelled during coughing, sneezing and talking though there is little experimental evidence to support this concept. Naturally infected patients discharge virus in large amounts from the nose but less frequently and less heavily from the throat. Although rhinoviruses are not shed readily from the upper respiratory tract on coughing or sneezing they may be found on the hands and fingers and can survive for up to three hours on non-porous surfaces. Virus can be transferred by infected fingers to the nasal or conjunctival mucosa. Rather surprisingly rhinoviruses do not survive on soiled handkerchiefs. Studies in Holland and the United States have shown that waves of colds arise simultaneously in different parts of the country. Since this can hardly result from person-to-person spread, some other explanation is necessary. It is conceivable that latent viruses in the respiratory tract are activated by changes in the weather or other factors. Colds are not highly infectious. It has been estimated that the chance of catching a cold from an infected relative is one in five and only about 10 per cent, of adults exposed to colds become infected. Respiratory viruses can be recovered from the upper air passages during the first few days of illness but quickly disappear with the onset of recovery. Mycoplasma is exceptional in persisting in secretions long after clinical recovery. Prolonged contact is necessary for spread of mycoplasmas and only a small proportion of those infected show evidence of active disease.

Respiratory viruses produce a range of syndromes varying greatly in severity and character. Some have a predilection for the upper respiratory passages, others for the lower but many are capable of invading both and the resistance of the host is the final determining factor. The respiratory syndromes are not sharply differentiated and in practice one merges into another. Nevertheless the pattern is sufficiently distinct to justify discussion under separate headings.

Common Cold. Everyone is familiar with the common cold since the average person living in an industrialised community has several attacks a year. At the onset there may be chilliness and slight fever with aching in the muscles of the limbs and back but constitutional disturbance is generally mild and the illness is dominated by respiratory symptoms. Soreness of the throat or a pricking sensation in the soft palate is quickly followed by profuse nasal discharge. Sneezing and watering of the eye ensue and a dry cough may develop. As the mucosa swells, breathing through the nose becomes difficult and the senses of smell and hearing may be impaired. At first the nasal secretions are clear and flow readily but within a few days become mucopurulent and tenacious. Herpes labialis is common. The nose and throat are inflamed and prominent lymph follicles may be seen on the posterior pharyngeal wall. The cervical lymph nodes may be slightly enlarged and tender. Sinusitis and catarrhal otitis media may add to the patient's dis comfort. In mild attacks symptoms subside within a week but severe attacks may persist for considerably longer.

Although a large variety of viruses may produce head colds, the most important are the rhinoviruses which affect all age groups. A proportion of colds are caused by influenza, parainfluenza, adenoviruses, respiratory syncytial viruses, enteroviruses and coronaviruses.

Pharyngitis is a component of most syndromes produced by respiratory viruses but occasionally throat symptoms predominate. Herpangina and lymphonodular pharyngitis due to Coxsackie A viruses have been discussed in Chapter 18 and herpes simplex gingivo-stomatitis in Chapter 3.

Adenoviruses may cause a feverish illness with a sore throat particularly in children. The onset is sudden with headache, shivering, sore throat and nasal obstruction. There is often vomiting or abdominal pain and occasionally diarrhoea with watery stools. During the acute stage the temperature may reach 40°C. Conjunctivitis is common and sticky discharge may mat the eyelashes. On examination the pharynx is inflamed and exudate may be found. The cervical lymph nodes are enlarged. The illness lasts 4 or 5 days and recovery is complete.

Croup. The connotation of the term "croup" has been extended to include any condition in which there is respiratory obstruction of inflammatory origin; it may therefore be a feature of epiglottitis, laryngitis and laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis. In infants and young children the larynx, trachea and bronchi are narrow and readily obstructed by swelling of the mucosa and accumulation of sticky secretions. Consequently 80 per cent, of attacks occur in children under 5 years.

In mild laryngitis constitutional disturbance is slight and obstruction to breathing absent or minimal. The outstanding features are hoarseness and a characteristic harsh barking cough. In severe attacks hoarseness becomes worse and obstruction rapidly develops to dominate the illness and threaten life. As breathing becomes distressed inspiratory stridor appears, followed by recession of the soft tissues in the neck and indrawing of the lower ribs at the insertion of the a. Bilateral subconjunctival haemorrhages in whoop ing cough.

With increasing obstruction stridor becomes continuous and recession more marked. Although in the early stages the child will lie peacefully and may even sleep, with the onset of anoxia he sits up desperately struggling for breath. A rising pulse rate gives warning of exhaustion and cyanosis introduces the terminal stage of circulatory collapse and death. In viral laryngitis the mucosa of the pharynx and the larynx is velvety and has a deep red colour. The main obstruc tion lies immediately below the vocal cords and is caused by inflammatory oedema of the mucous membrane aggravated by sticky mucopurulent exudate. Apart from stridor few signs are found on auscultation of the chest. Diphtheria should be considered in all patients with obstructive laryngitis (see Chapter 20). Epiglottitis, caused by Haemophilus influenza type B, may produce croup in children but examination of the throat will reveal an inflamed swollen epiglottitis. Infection may spread from the larynx into the trachea and bronchi causing acute laryngotracheo-bronchitis. When this happens breathing becomes more difficult and plugs of mucus may obstruct the smaller bronchi producing emphysema or atelectasis. Breath sounds are diminished and there is an expiratory wheeze. Patches of bronchial breathing and crepitations are often present.

Although great progress has been made in identifying viruses causing croup, the aetiology is only determined in a minority of attacks. Of the viruses so far discovered parainfluenza are the most important. Lesser roles are played by adenoviruses, respiratory syncytial virus, influenza virus, enteroviruses and rhinoviruses. Measles virus is a well-known cause of croup, laryngitis being a prominent feature of the prodromal phase.

At this stage the bronchioles are very narrow and readily occluded by swelling of the mucosa and accumulation of sticky exudate. When obstruction is complete trapped air is absorbed and atelectasis follows but in partial obstruction over-inflation is produced by a valve action, which allows air to enter but prevents it escaping. This combination of atelectasis and obstructive emphysema is responsible for the severe respiratory distress in bronchiolitis. The illness begins as a mild upper respiratory infection with nasal discharge, cough and slight fever. Within 2 to 4 days the infant's condition deteriorates rapidly with an alarming rise in respiration rate. Breathing is shallow and wheezy with prolongation of expiration. The soft tissues of the neck and chest wall are retracted. Coughing is incessant and may be paroxysmal. Cyanosis appears and is accentuated by coughing and crying. Because of difficulty in breathing and loss of appetite feeding is a problem. In severe attacks progressive anoxia leads to circulatory collapse and death. Bronchiolitis is a dangerous disease in young children and mortality rates of 2-7-6 per cent, have been recorded. When the outcome is favourable improvement commences on the fourth or fifth day but full recovery may take 2 or 3 weeks.
body_text.section: Acute Bronchiolitis. Acute bronchiolitis is found most frequently in children under 2 years

body_text.text: The physical signs are variable. In the early stages the breath sounds are diminished and adventitiae are absent. Later expiration becomes prolonged and fine crepitations are heard. Although the signs suggest bronchopneumonia, consolidation is not found on X-ray examination. The lung fields are abnormally transparent and the broncho-vascular markings prominent. Recent reports indicate that respiratory syncytial virus may be associated with maculo-papular or erythematous rashes simulating measles or rubella.
body_text.section: Acute Bronchiolitis. Acute bronchiolitis is found most frequently in children under 2 years

body_text.text: Respiratory syncytial virus is the agent most frequently isolated from children with bronchio litis. Numerous other agents have been incriminated including parainfluenza virus, mycoplasma, adenovirus, influenza virus and measles virus. Secondary bacterial infection may occur but is unusual. It has been postulated that the severe disturbance in the bronchioles of young children infected with respiratory syncytial virus might be a hypersensitivity reaction to complexes of the virus and IgG antibodies derived from the mother. The absence of specific IgA antibodies in the infant permits virus to penetrate the deeper layers of the bronchioles and combine with IgG. Primary Atypical Pneumonia. In 1934 Gallagher described a variety of pneumonia which could be distinguished clinically from bacterial pneumonia by its insidious onset, lack of pain and absence of clinical signs of consolidation. The radiological appearances were different and drugs proved ineffective. Subsequent studies have shown that this syndrome can be caused by myco plasma, Coxiella b urne ti and a number of viruses including respiratory syncytial virus, adenovirus, parainfluenza virus, psittacosis-ornithosis agent and influenza virus.
body_text.section: Acute Bronchiolitis. Acute bronchiolitis is found most frequently in children under 2 years

body_text.text: In adults the onset is insidious with headache, nasal discharge, sore throat and coughing but in children it may be more acute with shivering and feverishness. Fever is intermittent or irregular and lasts 7 to 10 days. There may be some tightness of the chest or soreness behind the sternum but pleural pain is rare. Initially coughing is unproductive but adults may later produce viscid mucoid or mucopurulent sputum. The throat is congested and the conjunctivae may be suffused. Chest signs are minimal with no evidence of consolidation but a few râles may be detected. Although the illness follows a variable course it is usually benign with full recovery in 1 to 3 weeks. Occasionally primary atypical pneumonia is complicated by polyneuritis, meningitis, encephalitis or haemolytic anaemia.
body_text.section: Acute Bronchiolitis. Acute bronchiolitis is found most frequently in children under 2 years

body_text.text: The appearance of the lungs on X-ray examination varies considerably and does not match the clinical state. Homogenous ground-glass opacities may be found in the periphery of the lungs or extend out like a fan from the hilum. In some areas the shadows may be discrete and miliary; in others confluent. The radiological changes may persist for days or weeks. Occasion ally the shadows migrate from one area to another. The white blood cell count is normal or slightly increased. In pneumonia caused by mycoplasma, cold agglutinins to human group O Mild respiratory symptoms, such as nasal discharge and coughing, may be present for a few days before fever appears. At the end of this prodromal period the temperature rises sharply with shivering and marked prostration. Headache, dizziness, myalgia and sweating are also prominent. In contrast to influenza, respiratory symptoms are troublesome from the start. Sneezing, nasal obstruction or discharge, soreness of the throat, hoarseness and a paroxysmal cough may be present. The conjunctivae are suffused and the throat congested with hypertrophied lymph follicles on the pharyngeal wall. The cervical lymph nodes are often slightly enlarged and tender. Physical examination of the chest seldom reveals more than mild bronchitis and radiological examination is usually negative. The white blood cell count is normal. Although constitutional symptoms are severe, with a temperature reaching 39-5-40°C, mortality is negligible. After 3 days fever generally subsides but in severe attacks convalescence may be prolonged with lassitude and persistent coughing.

body_text.text: Respiratory syndromes of virus origin overlap to such an extent that accurate diagnosis is seldom possible without laboratory aid. At present there is no spécifie treatment and laboratory investi gations are prolonged and complicated so have no immediate value for the clinician. Their main importance is to establish the pattern of disease, to determine the relative importance of viruses and to suggest means of prevention. It is often difficult to separate bacterial from viral infections of the respiratory tract. Isolation of a bacterial pathogen together with a polymorphonuclear leucocytosis in the blood provide strong presumptive evidence of primary or secondary bacterial invasion. Since virus culture is uncertain a rising antibody titre is generally the most satisfactory method of determining the aetiology of respiratory virus infections.

Collection of nose and throat swabs, nasal washings and garglings has already been discussed in Chapter 13. Although these are satisfactory for the majority of respiratory viruses, adenoviruses and enteroviruses are most readily recovered from faeces. Since respiratory syncytial virus does not remain viable for long at room temperature and does not survive freezing, suitable tissue cultures (Hela or HEp II) should be inoculated by the bedside. The remaining specimens should then be transported in a thermos flask containing ordinary ice.

Serological diagnosis depends on the production of antibodies against a specific virus. Antibodies may be detected, in vivo, by neutralisation tests in tissue and egg cultures or in vitro by haemagglutination-inhibition (HI) and complement-fixation test (CF). To establish a diagnosis blood should be obtained as early as possible in the acute stage of the illness and again during convalescence. A fourfold rise in antibody titre is significant. Serological tests for influenza have been described elsewhere (Chapter 13). Adenovirus infection may be diagnosed by a com plement-fixation test using Hela cell antigens but neutralisation and HI tests are necessary to identify the strain. In parainfluenzal infection it is desirable to recover the virus because serological responses overlap with mumps virus. Complement-fixation and neutralisation tests may be used for respiratory syncytical infections but direct recovery of virus is more sensitive particularly in infants. Infection with Mycoplasma pneumoniae may be suspected with positive cold agglutination or streptococcus MG tests but proof should be obtained by complementfixation or from antibodies detected by an immunofluorescent technique using frozen infected chick embryo lung. Ornithosis and Q fever may be diagnosed by complement-fixation tests. There are no suitable serological tests for rhinovirus infections.

Immunofluorescence affords a technique for the rapid diagnosis of certain respiratory infec tions, including influenza A and B, respiratory syncytial virus, parainfluenza viruses, adenoviruses and measles. Viral antigen is demonstrated in cells shed from the respiratory tract by treating

Common cold. Patients with feverish colds should rest in bed. Mild analgesics such as acetylsalicyclic acid and paracetemol give symptomatic relief. Decongestants are of doubtful value for many produce rebound congestion. Antibiotic sprays should not be used. Banks has drawn attention to the value of ascorbic acid and short courses of tetracycline or spiramycin in curtailing the purulent stage. To be effective these drugs must be given early when the nasal discharge is clear.
Pharyngitis. Treatment is entirely symptomatic and antibiotics should not be given. The patient should rest in bed during the acute stage. Analgesics and gargles help to relieve discomfort.

Croup is an alarming and dangerous condition requiring skilled attention and constant supervision. Children with mild attacks may be safely nursed at home but any deterioration warrants immediate admission to hospital. An accurate history and careful examination are essential to exclude diphtheria and Haemophilus influenzae epiglottitis, both of which require specific treatment. In all but the mildest cases high humidity is necessary to relieve obstruction. The child should be nursed in an oxygen tent or room at 21-24°C in an atmosphere supersaturated by a mechanical humidifier. The old-fashioned steam tent is potentially dangerous and tends to be too oppressive. The child should be disturbed as little as possible but sedation is ill-advised for it may mask the seriousness of the obstruction. With humidification most attacks are arrested but some progress rapidly. The danger signs are increasing dypsnoea, severe recession and most important of all, restlessness. At this stage hydrocortisone, 25 mg intravenously, may produce dramatic relief but if unsuccessful there should be no delay in performing tracheostomy. It is a serious mistake to wait until exhaustion or cyanosis supervene since these are signs of impending death. When obstruction is relieved by hydrocortisone, treatment should be continued for 2 or 3 days giving prednisolone by mouth, 5 mg 6-hourly. Antibiotics will have no effect on the under lying virus. In obstruction due to laryngitis tracheostomy gives immediate relief but is less effective in laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis. The tube can generally be removed after 5 days.

Bronchiolitis. Antibiotics are useless in the average attack of bronchiolitis and should only be given when life is threatened or bacterial complications are suspected. The essential treatment for severe bronchiolitis is oxygen, which may be administered most effectively in a high humidity tent. Children of all ages are nursed most comfortably in the sitting position. When feeding is a problem in babies, clear fluids may be given by nasal tube. Sedatives are rarely required but when a child is restless in an oxygen tent small doses of promethazine are rapidly effective. Digitalis is occasionally required for congestive heart failure as shown by a rising pulse rate and enlarging liver. In grave cases corticosteroids may be life saving but should not be used routinely.

Primary Atypical Pneumonia. Viral forms of pneumonia do not respond to antibiotic treatment but pneumonia caused by mycoplasma, ornithosis agent and Cox. burneti may respond to tetracycline. Oxygen therapy is seldom necessary.
"Influenzai" Illness. Treatment is symptomatic and antibiotics are contra-indicated.

Acute febrile respiratory diseases resembling influenza are caused by several viruses including parainfluenza viruses, adenoviruses, Coxsackie virus A21 (Coe), group B Coxsackie viruses, ECHO virus type 20 and others.

back_matter.text: At present there are no effective means of preventing acute respiratory virus infections. Active immunisation using living or killed vaccines is still experimental but the multiplicity of viruses and the absence of cross immunity make success unlikely. Adenovirus vaccines, inactivated by formalin or heat, provoke antibodies against homologous serotypes and have been used in military camps where such infections are common but their use has been suspended pending further investigation of the oncogenic properties of the virus. Experiments with rhinovirus vaccines inactivated by formalin have shown that they prevent illness and shedding of virus but do not prevent subclinical infection. Antibodies persist for 12-18 months. Since immunity is type specific and there are over 100 serotypes mass immunisation is hardly practicable. In Britain the more serious forms of psittacosis-ornithosis may be effectively controlled by careful quarantine of parrots and parakeets.
